results.description: Field suggestions enabled - potential information disclosure
results.evidence: Found "did you mean" in error message - field suggestions are enabled

results.description: The GraphQL error responses include explicit field suggestions and the names of types/fields (e.g., 'title', 'body', 'id', 'user', 'CreatePostInput', 'userId'). This leaks schema information that allows an attacker to enumerate available types and fields and craft more effective queries. While not an injection or direct data leak, it is an information-disclosure vulnerability that aids reconnaissance and increases attack surface. Remediation: return generic validation errors in production or disable suggestion output; restrict error detail to authenticated/admin contexts and implement rate-limiting and logging to detect enumeration attempts.
results.evidence: Error messages: "Cannot query field \"titl\" on type \"Post\". Did you mean \"title\"?", "Cannot query field \"bod\" on type \"Post\". Did you mean \"body\" or \"id\"?", "Cannot query field \"usr\" on type \"Post\". Did you mean \"user\"?", plus: "Field \"userId\" is not defined by type \"CreatePostInput\"."

Did you mean \"body\" or \"id\"?", "Cannot query field \"usr\" on type \"Post\". Did you mean \"user\"?", plus: "Field \"userId\" is not defined by type \"CreatePostInput\"."
llm_analysis.explanation: The GraphQL error responses include explicit field suggestions and the names of types/fields (e.g., 'title', 'body', 'id', 'user', 'CreatePostInput', 'userId'). This leaks schema information that allows an attacker to enumerate available types and fields and craft more effective queries. While not an injection or direct data leak, it is an information-disclosure vulnerability that aids reconnaissance and increases attack surface. Remediation: return generic validation errors in production or disable suggestion output; restrict error detail to authenticated/admin contexts and implement rate-limiting and logging to detect enumeration attempts.

results.description: The GraphQL error responses include "Did you mean ...?" suggestions that reveal correct field names (e.g., title, body, name). These suggestion messages disclose schema information and valid field names, which can aid an attacker in enumerating the API schema and constructing valid queries even if introspection is disabled. Although this does not directly expose sensitive data or indicate injection, it is an information disclosure risk that can make further probing and automated fuzzing more effective. Recommend suppressing or normalizing such detailed validation messages in production (return generic errors or a single validation error code) to avoid leaking schema details.
results.evidence: Error messages in response: "Cannot query field \"titel\" on type \"Post\". Did you mean \"title\"?", "Cannot query field \"boddy\" on type \"Post\". Did you mean \"body\"?", "Cannot query field \"nme\" on type \"User\". Did you mean \"name\"?"

llm_analysis.evidence: Error messages in response: "Cannot query field \"titel\" on type \"Post\". Did you mean \"title\"?", "Cannot query field \"boddy\" on type \"Post\". Did you mean \"body\"?", "Cannot query field \"nme\" on type \"User\". Did you mean \"name\"?"
llm_analysis.explanation: The GraphQL error responses include "Did you mean ...?" suggestions that reveal correct field names (e.g., title, body, name). These suggestion messages disclose schema information and valid field names, which can aid an attacker in enumerating the API schema and constructing valid queries even if introspection is disabled. Although this does not directly expose sensitive data or indicate injection, it is an information disclosure risk that can make further probing and automated fuzzing more effective. Recommend suppressing or normalizing such detailed validation messages in production (return generic errors or a single validation error code) to avoid leaking schema details.

results.description: Field suggestions enabled - potential information disclosure
results.evidence: Found "did you mean" in error message - field suggestions are enabled

results.description: The GraphQL response returns corrective suggestions and explicit type/field names in error messages (e.g., suggesting 'title', 'body', 'name' and revealing that 'userId' is not defined on CreatePostInput). This discloses schema details to unauthenticated/attacker-controlled clients, enabling schema enumeration and more targeted probing or exploitation. While not an immediate code-execution vulnerability, leaking schema structure increases the attack surface and aids further attacks (reconnaissance, crafting queries, finding hidden fields). Recommended mitigation: suppress or genericize server error messages, disable automatic 'did you mean' suggestions in production, and implement error masking/logging that does not expose schema details to clients.

llm_analysis.explanation: The GraphQL response returns corrective suggestions and explicit type/field names in error messages (e.g., suggesting 'title', 'body', 'name' and revealing that 'userId' is not defined on CreatePostInput). This discloses schema details to unauthenticated/attacker-controlled clients, enabling schema enumeration and more targeted probing or exploitation. While not an immediate code-execution vulnerability, leaking schema structure increases the attack surface and aids further attacks (reconnaissance, crafting queries, finding hidden fields). Recommended mitigation: suppress or genericize server error messages, disable automatic 'did you mean' suggestions in production, and implement error masking/logging that does not expose schema details to clients.

results.description: Field suggestions enabled - potential information disclosure
results.evidence: Found "did you mean" in error message - field suggestions are enabled

results.description: The GraphQL response returns a validation error that includes a suggested field name ("Did you mean 'title'?"). This is clear evidence of field suggestion information leakage: the API is exposing schema-level details that allow an attacker to discover valid field names on types (in this case, the 'Post' type). While this does not directly expose sensitive data, it facilitates schema enumeration and targeted probing which can increase the risk of data exposure or enable further exploitation. Recommended mitigation: suppress detailed error messages in production (do not return suggestion hints), or return generic validation errors and restrict introspection where appropriate.

Recommended mitigation: suppress detailed error messages in production (do not return suggestion hints), or return generic validation errors and restrict introspection where appropriate.

results.description: HTML injection vulnerability detected - HTML markup found in response
results.evidence: Response status: 200, HTML patterns detected in response data

results.description: The GraphQL response returns unescaped HTML in the 'body' field: an <iframe> referencing an attacker-controlled domain. If a client application injects this value into a web page DOM without escaping or sanitization, it enables HTML injection (a form of XSS) allowing an attacker to load arbitrary remote content, perform clickjacking, exfiltrate data, or execute scripts depending on rendering context. This is clear evidence of HTML/markup being returned from the API. Recommend treating user content as untrusted: escape/encode HTML when rendering, apply a strict Content Security Policy, sanitize or remove dangerous tags/attributes on input or output (e.g., disallow <iframe>, <script>, inline event handlers), and validate/encode fields at the client/server boundary.

llm_analysis.explanation: The GraphQL response returns unescaped HTML in the 'body' field: an <iframe> referencing an attacker-controlled domain. If a client application injects this value into a web page DOM without escaping or sanitization, it enables HTML injection (a form of XSS) allowing an attacker to load arbitrary remote content, perform clickjacking, exfiltrate data, or execute scripts depending on rendering context. This is clear evidence of HTML/markup being returned from the API. Recommend treating user content as untrusted: escape/encode HTML when rendering, apply a strict Content Security Policy, sanitize or remove dangerous tags/attributes on input or output (e.g., disallow <iframe>, <script>, inline event handlers), and validate/encode fields at the client/server boundary.

errors.message: Cannot query field "createPost" on type "Query".

results.description: The GraphQL error message reveals schema-level information by stating that the field 'createPost' is not present on the 'Query' type. Although this response is not an explicit __schema introspection result, it leaks type/field information and shows the server returns detailed validation errors that can be used to enumerate schema structure (e.g., which operations are queries vs. mutations and which fields exist). This constitutes an information-disclosure/introspection risk. Impact is limited because only partial schema details are disclosed via error messages (not a full introspection dump), so severity is LOW, but this can aid attackers in targeted probing. Recommend returning generic error messages in production, disabling GraphQL introspection where appropriate, and enforcing access controls on schema discovery.

llm_analysis.explanation: The GraphQL error message reveals schema-level information by stating that the field 'createPost' is not present on the 'Query' type. Although this response is not an explicit __schema introspection result, it leaks type/field information and shows the server returns detailed validation errors that can be used to enumerate schema structure (e.g., which operations are queries vs. mutations and which fields exist). This constitutes an information-disclosure/introspection risk. Impact is limited because only partial schema details are disclosed via error messages (not a full introspection dump), so severity is LOW, but this can aid attackers in targeted probing. Recommend returning generic error messages in production, disabling GraphQL introspection where appropriate, and enforcing access controls on schema discovery.

results.description: Field suggestions enabled - potential information disclosure

results.description: The GraphQL error responses include explicit "Did you mean ...?" suggestions that reveal valid field names on the Post type (title, body). This is a form of information disclosure (field_suggestions) that aids schema discovery and can make automated probing and targeted attacks easier. While the disclosed data here is limited to field names (low sensitivity), exposing schema hints in production increases attack surface. Remediation: disable or remove "did you mean" suggestions / detailed validation hints in production (e.g., turn off debug/pretty errors), return generic validation errors, or gate schema introspection behind authorization.
